java.lang.String.value:
The Google Maps library enables convertigo projects to access GoogleMaps features. 
This library has two parts : A Visual Widget handled by the GoogleMapsConnector to be inserted in Mashup Composer and A Web service API to be used in sequencer projects handled by the GoogleMapsApiConnector.
This connector will handle the Service API part of the GoogleMaps. Service APIs has no presentation widget and are intended to be used by sequencer projects. \n

Geocoding is the process of converting addresses (like "1600 Amphitheatre Parkway, Mountain View, CA") into geographic coordinates (like latitude 37.423021 and longitude -122.083739), which you can use to place markers or position the map.
This test case will test the GeoCodingApi with an Address situated in Paris
6 rue Labrouste, Paris, France
new variable
Specify here a 'Google Compatible' address. This can be any like 'San Francisco', or 'Market street, San Francisco'
Indicates whether or not the geocoding request comes from a device with a location sensor. This value must be either true or false

The term geocoding generally refers to translating a human-readable address into a location on a map. The process of doing the converse, translating a location on the map into a human-readable address, is known as reverse geocoding. \n \nThe Geocoding API supports reverse geocoding directly using the latlng parameter.
Lat and Lng in <lat>,<lng> format
Specify here a Lat Lng Parameter in the form <lat>,<lng> such as "48.8343840,2.3084275"
Indicates whether or not the geocoding request comes from a device with a location sensor. This value must be either true or false
This connector handles the visual part of the GoogleMaps libray
Call this transaction to mark a new location on the current map.
Specify here a 'Google Compatible' address. This can be any like 'San Francisco', or 'Market street, San Francisco'

This is the first transaction to call. It will result in displaying a GoogleMaps widget centered on the location provided, with the specified parameters.
